In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Following the request from the Government of Nepal for capacity development technical 
assistance  (TA)  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  strengthen  the  capacities  of 
municipalities, ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2010–2012 made a provision for TA for 
Strengthening Municipalities for Urban Service Delivery.1 The country operations business plan, 
2012–2014 reconfirmed the processing of this TA. 
 
2.  An ADB fact-finding mission visited Nepal from 24 August to 2 September 2011. This 
report  is  based  on  the  understandings  reached  with  the  government  during  the  mission 
regarding  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing 
arrangements, and outline terms of reference for the TA.2 The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Urban  development  in  Nepal.  In  the  past,  urban  development  often  assumed  a 
secondary importance to rural development. Consequently, municipalities are characterized by 
inadequate drinking-water supply, sanitation, drainage, solid waste management, and transport 
infrastructure  and  facilities.  Serious  environmental  issues,  including  an  increased  level  of 
vehicular pollution, haphazard disposal of solid waste and wastewater, and illegal dumping of 
industrial waste into rivers and streams, are emerging because of uncontrolled and haphazard 
urban development. Insufficient financial resources and qualified human resources, and a low 
level of institutional capacity leave urban authorities unable to cope with the growing demand for 
services by providing commensurate infrastructural facilities. Issues and challenges that the TA 
will address are detailed in the subsequent paragraphs. 
 
4.  Financial  management  including  revenue  enhancement.  Mobilization  of financial 
resources by municipalities is hampered by the lack of a sound financial management system 
and  innovative  approaches  to  developing  institutional  capacity  to  manage  financial  affairs. 
Municipalities  are  largely  dependent  on  the  central  government,  whose  grants  and  loans 
account for a significant portion of their total revenue. There is an urgent need to increase 
internal revenue by assessing potential sources, such as broadening the tax base, updating 
property  tax  valuations,  and  increasing  collection  efficiency.3 Under  the  previous  capacity 
development TA, a review of the current financial management system was carried out for 
Dharan, Janakpur, Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar, the four municipalities participating in the 
current TA.4 That review covered revenue administration management, types of taxes and non-
taxes, the status of application of the integrated property tax, the collection level and efficiency 
of taxes and non-taxes over the years, assessment methods of tax valuation, staff capacity, and 
the potential for revenue enhancement. The review also covered the current accounting and 
audit systems, practices, and recording status, including the level of computerization of the 
accounting  system,  a  plan  to  reduce  backlogs  in  financial  data  entry,  adoption  of  annual 
financial statements, and internal and external audits of annual financial statements. Based on 
the review, a comprehensive financial management improvement plan (CFMIP) was prepared 
for each participating municipality. The plan, which covers 5 years, needs to be implemented.

5.  Most internal audit units are not in place, and internal audits are essentially irregular in 
frequency  and  not  effective.  Backlog  of  internal  audits  is  quite  common  in  municipalities. 
Accumulated advances are high and generally not settled in time. The practice of periodic 
reconciliations  varies  from  municipality  to  municipality  with  reconciliations  done  monthly, 
quarterly, semiannually or annually when they should be carried out monthly. Efforts need to be 
made  to  improve  the  accounting  system,  quality  of  audit  reports,  when  such  reports  are 
produced, as well as the time taken for reconciliations. 
 
6.  Urban planning. Municipalities and emerging towns have developed haphazardly in the 
absence of stringent policy regulating and managing growth. Unplanned growth has created a 
number of problems: deficiencies in basic urban services, lack of sanitation and solid waste 
management systems, environmental degradation, and encroachment of settlements on public 
lands,  forests,  and  rivers.  Legislative  support,  institutional  strengthening,  and  community 
empowerment are needed to enable municipalities to implement municipal building bylaws and 
national building codes. 
 
7.  Geographic information system–based urban mapping. Many municipalities still lack 
proper base maps. Although the participating municipalities have or are developing basic digital 
base maps, they have no software to run the geographic information system (GIS), and only 
very limited information and data are available in the GIS. The existing maps do not support the 
functions that municipalities need to perform. With rapid urbanization, there is a strong need to 
develop and update large-scale, GIS-based urban maps using an adequate socioeconomic 
database.  Updated maps  will  bring multiple  benefits  because  they  can  be  used for many 
purposes:  better  urban  and  project  planning,  a  better  tax  information  base,  and  better 
engineering of public works. 
 
8.  Participating  municipalities.  The  TA  will  primarily  target  four  municipalities  where 
investment projects are planned with ADB funding under the Integrated Urban Development 
Project: Dharan, Janakpur, Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar.5 These municipalities, which are 
important urban centers in their regions, have high economic growth potential but suffer from 
serious deficits of urban infrastructure. The TA complements the urban development project by 
developing institutional capacity to ensure effective, efficient implementation as well as financial 
and technical sustainability of the improvements in service delivery. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  expected  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  stronger  institutional  capacity  in  Dharan, 
Janakpur, Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar for urban service delivery. Stronger capacity will be 
measured by improvements in service levels of urban infrastructure and in services provided. 
The  outcomes  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  financial  management  and  strengthened  urban

developed under the previous TA. The previous TA activities were completed in October 2011, but additional 
support is required to implement the CFMIP and make the GIS fully functional. Being the implementing agencies of

planning in Dharan, Janakpur, Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar. These two outcomes will be 
measured by (i) an increase in the internal revenue of municipalities, (ii) public disclosure of 
amended  building  bylaws,  and  (iii)  new  buildings  constructed  in  compliance  with  building 
permits issued by participating municipalities under the amended building bylaws and national 
building codes. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will have six outputs. The major activities of each output are as follows:  
 
11.  Output 1: Tax net extended for property tax. To improve the internal revenues of the 
municipalities, the cadastre for properties owned by individuals and businesses needs to be 
expanded. The current tax net coverage is estimated at about 60%, with only partial registration 
of identified taxpayers in the database. This output is intended to provide support to register all 
properties  and  owners  (i.e.,  taxpayers)  in  the  cadastral  database.  The  scope  of  services 
consists of assisting the municipalities in (i) preparing awareness campaigns to present the 
services provided by the municipalities and motivate taxpayers to register, and (ii) entering data 
in the database during the campaigns. 
 
12.  Output 2: Internal audit carried out regularly and as per standard. The scope of 
services consists of assisting the municipalities in implementing the CFMIP by audit unit and 
supporting the preparation of internal audit reports. Issues addressed under this output will 
include (i) insufficient accounting and auditing systems, and (ii) irregularities reported in the 
audit report. 
 
13.  Output 3: Staff skills enhanced in accounting, budgeting, and internal auditing. 
The  scope  of  services  consists  of  assisting  the  municipalities  in  implementing  the  CFMIP 
through disseminating the plan and consulting stakeholders, preparing internal guidelines and 
manuals, conducting training programs, and monitoring action plans so that the municipalities 
can sustain implementation after the consultancy services are completed. 
 
14.  Output 4: Amended building bylaws approved. This output is intended to strengthen 
urban planning by assisting the municipalities in (i) reviewing and revising building bylaws 
delineating urban functions in municipalities, and (ii) implementing building bylaws and national 
building codes. The amended building bylaws will be approved by the municipal councils. 
 
15.  Output 5: GIS-based urban maps used for taxation and urban service delivery. 
This  output  is  intended  to  strengthen  urban  planning  by  assisting  the  municipalities  in 
developing a complete and effective GIS-based municipal information system. Information in the 
maps will include administrative boundaries, topographic features such as contour lines and 
land  use,  transportation  infrastructure,  utilities  infrastructure,  buildings,  cadastral  data,  and 
socioeconomic  data.  The  maps  will  be  used  to  establish  an  effective  house  and  street 
addressing system. The system will also link the GIS with the property and business taxation 
system of the municipality and be the basis for updating the municipalities’ cadastres. 
 
16.  Output  6:  Staff  skills  enhanced  for  GIS-based  urban  mapping.  Capacity 
development programs will be undertaken for municipal staff to institutionalize the use of the 
GIS-based  municipal  information  system  and  optimize  it  for  municipal  decision  making, 
including tax mapping, infrastructure planning, and public works engineering.

4   
17.  Risks.  The  municipalities  have  lacked  elected  mayors  and  municipal  council 
representatives  since  2002.  Considering  the  current  political  conditions,  this  situation  may 
continue. It causes a lack of accountability and leadership in improving the performance of 
municipal functions. Furthermore, executive officers acting as mayors of municipalities, deputed 
from the Ministry of Local Development (MLD), are often transferred within a short time, which 
impedes the continued strong commitment of municipality leaders. This risk will be minimized 
through close consultations with political parties at the municipal level. The TA’s links with the 
forthcoming  investment  project  will  help  create  strong  municipal  and  public  support  for 
improving the capacity and performance of municipalities. The selection criteria and process for 
identifying municipalities with relatively higher capacities both help improve the chances of 
success of the TA and mitigate risks. One risk is that the new constitution that the government is 
formulating could affect the local governance system. However, the TA is in line with the general 
direction of the government toward strengthening devolution, and the functions of municipalities 
are largely expected to remain as they are. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The government has asked ADB to finance the equivalent of $1 million. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  office  space,  remuneration  for 
counterpart  staff  (including  their  field  per  diem  and  transportation),  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The  MLD  and  the  Ministry  of  Physical  Planning  and  Works  (MPPW),  through  the 
Department of Urban Development and Building Construction (DUDBC), will be the executing 
agency. The MLD will assign the chief of the municipal planning section (undersecretary) as a 
TA coordinator to coordinate and supervise the work for outputs 1–3, while the DUDBC will 
assign the chief of the urban development division (deputy director general) as a TA coordinator 
for outputs 4–6. The two TA coordinators will collaborate closely and be jointly responsible for 
supervising the TA. At the central level, a steering committee will be established to monitor TA 
implementation. The steering committee, which will be co-chaired by the secretaries of the 
MPPW and the  MLD,  will  consist  of  high-level  representatives from  the  National  Planning 
Commission, the Ministry of Finance, the MLD, the MPPW, the Secretariat of the Local Body 
Fiscal Commission, the Municipal Association of Nepal, participating municipalities, the Town 
Development Fund, and the DUDBC. The TA coordinators will work as members and conveners 
of the steering committee. Technical departments and institutions (such as the Department of 
Water Supply and Sewerage, the Department of Roads, and the Solid Waste Management 
Technical Support Center) will be invited whenever relevant issues are on the agenda. The 
steering committee will meet at least quarterly to discuss overall progress and provide policy 
guidance  to  the  TA.  At  each  participating  municipality,  a  focal  person  for  the  TA  will  be 
appointed and a working committee established to work closely with the TA consultants. The 
working committee will comprise representatives from town development committees, as well as 
sections  or  subsections  on  revenue,  accounting,  audit,  urban  planning,  GIS,  water  and 
sanitation, transport, solid waste management, and any other relevant fields. Local offices of 
technical departments and institutions will be closely involved with outputs 4–6. 
 
20.  The government will provide (i) all relevant documents, data, statistics, information, and 
maps that are at its disposal; (ii) appropriate and qualified counterpart staff, including their field 
per diem and field transportation; (iii) TA coordinators from the MLD and the DUDBC, to be

5 
assigned before the consultants’ mobilization; (iv) TA focal persons and counterpart staff from 
each participating municipality, to be assigned before the consultants’ mobilization; (v) office 
accommodation and office equipment, including desks and chairs, and local communication for 
outputs 1–3 in the MLD and outputs 4–6 in DUDBC; (vi) logistical assistance for the workshops 
and seminars, including providing the venue, and identifying and inviting the participants; and 
(vii) utility costs, covering electricity and water. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from July 2012 to June 2014. The outline 
terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. International expertise (9 person-months) 
will be obtained in urban planning and management information systems. National consultants 
(80 person-months) will have expertise in urban planning, financial management, information 
systems, and GIS. In addition, individual consultants may be engaged to address specific needs 
of the participating municipalities. 
 
22.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A team of consultants will be recruited under 
one package using the quality- and cost-based method of selection, with a standard quality–cost 
ratio of 80:20. A simplified technical proposal will be used for the selection of the consultant firm. 
The consultants will assist the government in organizing the workshops at the beginning of the 
TA and toward its completion. The overall framework and approach, objectives, and targets of 
the TA will be shared at the first workshop with relevant government agencies and municipalities. 
The final workshop will be held to disseminate good practices and lessons from the TA for 
replication and scaling up. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
23.  Some equipment (such as computers, printers, and GIS software) will be procured under 
the TA using the shopping method, in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, 
as amended from time to time). The government will ensure proper storage and appropriate use 
of the equipment and software placed in participating municipalities during TA implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of TA not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to the Government 
of Nepal for Strengthening Municipalities for Urban Service Delivery, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objective 
1.  The  objective  of  the  assignment  is  to  strengthen  capacity  of  Dharan,  Janakpur, 
Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar municipalities for improved urban service delivery. 
 
2.  The  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  be  closely  linked  to  the 
proposed Integrated Urban Development Project. One of the outputs of the Integrated Urban 
Development Project is to develop municipal infrastructure. The purpose of the TA is to support 
the sustainability of the infrastructure through stronger institutional capacity in Dharan, Janakpur, 
Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar municipalities. The TA will have six outputs grouped under two 
components: (i) improving the financial management system, including revenue enhancement; 
and (ii) strengthening urban planning by developing and implementing building bylaws and 
building codes supported by geographic information system (GIS)–based municipal information 
system. 
 
B.  Scope of Assignment 
3.  The TA will require 89 person-months of consulting services (9 international and 80 
national). The consultants’ work will build upon existing studies undertaken on the subject, 
including those carried out under previous TA projects.6 While the focus of the support will be 
placed on the four participating municipalities, follow-up support will be provided to Biratnagar, 
Birgunj,  and  Butwal  municipalities,  where  the  comprehensive  financial  management 
improvement  plan  (CFMIP)  has  been  prepared  and  GIS-based  urban  maps  have  been 
developed.  The  consultants  will  closely  work  with  the  four  participating  municipalities  in 
undertaking the tasks, in coordination with the Ministry of Local Development for component 1 
and the Department of Urban Development and Building Construction for component 2. 
 
1.  Component 1: Improvement of Financial Management System 
 
4.  The tasks are: 
(i)  increase in municipal internal revenue through tax net extension: (a) prepare 
public  awareness  campaign  on  municipal  taxes:  draft  campaign  plan  with 
objectives,  population  target,  detailed  action  plans,  and  corresponding  event 
schedule; (b) prepare and organize tax registration campaign: assist in drafting 
public announcements and provide logistical support; and (c) assist municipal 
staff in inputting property taxpayer information in taxpayer database, including 
linkage with GIS-based maps; 
(ii)  implementation of the CFMIP: (a) organize workshops for CFMIP dissemination 
and stakeholder consultation (including presentations and leaflets if required); (b) 
review  the  existing  expenditure  and  revenue  accounting  system  to  identify 
deficiencies; (c) based on the review, propose software improvements; (d) based 
on the recommendations of the CFMIP, assess training needs and prepare a 
detailed staff capacity development plan for accounting, budgeting, and internal 
auditing;  (e)  prepare  a  training  plan  on  accounting,  budgeting,  and  internal 
auditing  for  the  use  of  software;  (f)  prepare  corresponding  guidelines  and

implement a training program; (j) prepare detailed action plans to implement the 
CFMIP, including revenue enhancement measures using output 1; (j) monitor 
implementation  of  the  detailed  action  plan;  (k)  provide  regular  on-the-job 
assistance through email and regular visits; and (l) provide one refresher session 
for accounting, budgeting, and internal auditing before the end of assignment; 
and 
(iii)  internal audit: (a) review the internal audit work plan and suggest improvements, 
if necessary; (b) assist in preparing the first internal audit report following the 
standards defined in the manual (see implementation of the CFMIP); and (c) 
prepare monthly  internal  audit  reports following  the  standards  defined  in the 
manual. 
 
2.  Component 2: Strengthening Urban Planning 
 
5.  The tasks are: 
(i)  support in preparation and amendment of applicable municipal bylaws: (a) review 
existing building bylaws and codes, and propose amendments in accordance with 
urban development plans; (b) prepare an action plan for implementation and 
enforcement  (including  a  monitoring  and  evaluation  methodology  for 
implementation) of building bylaws and national building codes; and (c) provide 
support for and monitoring of implementation of the action plan; and 
(ii)  GIS-based  maps:  (a)  assess  staff  capacity  and  the  existing  urban  mapping 
system;  identify  an  improvement  methodology  and  needs  for  hardware  and 
software; (b) assess training needs, and prepare and implement a detailed staff 
training  plan;  (c)  prepare  detailed  operation  manuals  for  GIS-based  map 
utilization  and  training  for  GIS-based  map  utilization;  (d)  undertake  a 
socioeconomic  survey  (100%  house-level  coverage)  and  development  of 
cadastral information; (e) prepare upgraded and updated digital base maps at 
1:2,500 scale for urban areas and at 1:5,000 scale for the remaining areas, will 
including buildings, roads, major landmarks, and other visible features as well as 
utilities such as water supply lines, the sewerage network, and street lighting; (f) 
establish and implement an effective house and street addressing system; (g) 
provide  appropriate  GIS  software  and  hardware;  (h)  customize  software  to 
establish links with the taxation system and real estate asset inventory; (i) provide 
regular on-the-job assistance through email and regular visits; (j) provide one 
refresher session before the end of the assignment; and (k) organize workshops 
to disseminate best practices. 
 
C.  Indicative Expertise Requirements 
6.  Urban planning expert (international, 6 person-months). The expert should have a 
postgraduate degree in urban planning or relevant fields and at least 10 years of international 
experience working on urban planning (including enforcement of building bylaws and building 
codes, and GIS-based urban mapping), including work experience in at least two developing 
countries, preferably in South Asia. He or she will undertake component 2. Specifically, he or 
she will (i) supervise the work undertaken by the national urban planning specialists; (ii) review 
and assess current practices and problems in participating municipalities; (iii) provide concrete,

12  Appendix 3 
workable,  and  innovative  suggestions  and  recommendations  reflecting  international  good 
practices; and (iv) ensure the quality of consultants’ inputs and the TA outputs. He or she will 
supervise  the  preparation  and  approval  of  building  bylaws  and  implementation  of capacity 
development programs for municipality staff. 
 
7.  Management information system expert (international, 3 person-months). The expert 
should have a postgraduate degree in system engineering or relevant fields and at least 10 
years of international experience in management information systems in at least two developing 
countries. Work  experience  in  South  Asia  and  a  good  understanding  of  local  government 
finance and accounting in the region are highly desirable. He or she will make the effective links 
between component 1 and component 2. Specifically, he or she will (i) guide the national 
financial management specialist and the national information system specialist; (ii) assist in the 
implementation of relevant plans, including progress reviews; and (iii) ensure the quality of 
consultants’ inputs and the TA outputs. He or she will provide inputs to capacity development 
programs for municipality staff in revenue collection and accounting in relation to management 
information systems. 
 
8.  Team leader and senior urban planning specialist (national, 18 person-months). The 
team leader should have a postgraduate degree in urban planning or relevant fields and at least 
10 years of experience in urban planning or urban governance. A good understanding in a 
broad range of urban management and experience working for the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) or other development partners’ projects in the urban sector is highly desirable. As team 
leader, he or she will (i) manage the overall implementation of the TA; (ii) prepare a task matrix 
for consultants and counterparts; (iii) ensure timely inputs from the international consultants; (iv) 
supervise the quality of inputs from the national consultants; (v) coordinate closely with the 
executing agency, participating municipalities, and ADB; (vi) coordinate and supervise capacity 
development programs implemented for each output for best outcomes; and (vii) be responsible 
for  delivering  various  components  under  the  TA.  The  team  leader  will  ensure  smooth 
coordination and linkage among components. For technical matters, the consultant will work 
under the guidance of international experts. He or she will act as a focal point to coordinate with 
the Department of Urban Development and Building Construction. 
 
9.  Urban planning specialist (national, 10 person-months). The specialist should have a 
postgraduate degree in urban planning or relevant fields and at least 7 years of experience in 
urban planning. A good understanding of the preparation and implementation of building bylaws 
and national building codes  is highly desirable. Legal knowledge and experience is highly 
advantageous.  He  or  she  will  (i)  review  existing  building  bylaws  and  codes;  (ii)  propose 
amendments of the building bylaws; and (iii) prepare an action plan for implementation and 
enforcement, including a monitoring and evaluation methodology for the implementation of 
building bylaws and building codes. 
 
10.  Deputy  team  leader  and  financial  management  specialist  (national,  10  person-
months). The deputy team leader should have a postgraduate degree in finance, accounting, or 
relevant fields and at least 10 years of experience working in municipal finance, accounting, or 
auditing. He or she will take the lead in assisting the municipalities in disseminating as well as 
implementing  the  CFMIP,  particularly  for  revenue  enhancement,  together  with  capacity 
development programs for municipality staff, and information disclosure of documents drafted 
under this TA. He or she will act as a focal point to coordinate with the Ministry of Local 
Development.

Appendix 3  13 
11.  Accountant (national, 10 person-months). The accountant will take the lead in preparing 
detailed trainings and workshops based on the current accounting and audit system, practices, 
and recording status, including the level of computerization of the accounting system available 
in the participating municipalities and targets identified in the CFMIP. He or she will prepare 
detailed action plans to reduce backlogs in processing financial data, adopting annual financial 
statements, and conducting annual internal audits. In collaboration with the national financial 
management specialist, he or she will assist the municipalities in implementing the CFMIP, 
together with capacity development programs for the municipalities’ staff, with specific focus on 
accounting, budgeting, and auditing. 
 
12.  Information  system  specialist  (national,  18 person-months). The  specialist  should 
have a postgraduate degree in computer science, system engineering, or relevant fields and at 
least 10 years of experience in GIS. A good understanding of various GIS software programs is 
required, and experience in urban GIS-based mapping is essential. The specialist will work 
under the guidance of the international urban planning expert and lead the work of developing 
and institutionalizing the GIS-based municipal information system. He or she will (i) assess the 
staff capacity level and the existing urban mapping system; (ii) identify an efficient improvement 
methodology and needs for hardware and software; (iii) identify the features to be captured in 
the  maps,  including  administrative  boundaries,  topographic  features,  cadastral  data, 
infrastructure, and buildings; (iv) prepare updated digital base maps at 1:2,500 scale for urban 
areas and at 1:5,000 scale for the remaining areas by using aerial photographs and satellite 
imagery; (v) conduct field verification surveys; (vi) develop the cadastral information system; (vii) 
undertake a socioeconomic survey (100% house-level coverage); (viii) establish an effective 
house and street addressing (numbering) system; (ix) link the tax system with the GIS-based 
maps; and (x) undertake staff training to equip relevant staff with the skills necessary to utilize, 
produce, interpret, and analyze outputs from the mapping system for decision making and to 
update  the  maps,  including  demonstration  and  dissemination  of  actual  usage  of  various 
thematic  maps.  He  or  she  will  customize  the  software  to  link  the  GIS  system  with  the 
municipalities’ taxation system. 
 
13.  Geographic  information  system  programming  specialist  (national,  14  person-
months). The specialist will support the work of the information system specialist in preparing 
GIS-based urban maps, particularly for preparing and institutionalizing programs that could 
effectively assist municipalities in performing their duties, such as tax collection and recording, 
undertaking urban planning and engineering designs, and managing assets and facilities. 
 
D.  Reporting 
14.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 6 weeks from the start of the TA, 
finalizing the approach and presenting a detailed work plan and implementation schedule for the 
TA; (ii) a progress report every quarter, summarizing the progress, problems, and challenges 
identified  and  actions  taken  or  proposed  to  be  taken  to  address  them  as  well  as  major 
achievements  to  be  noted  and  shared  with  other  municipalities  and  the  government,  and 
programs planned for the next quarter; (iii) a draft final report 20 months from the start of the TA, 
presenting all activities undertaken and results achieved, an assessment of achievements in 
comparison to original targets, a review of problems encountered during implementation and 
actions  taken  or  proposed  to  be  taken  to  remedy  these  problems,  and  proposed 
recommendations for future short- to medium-term programs, with clear presentation of actors, 
actions, time frame, performance indicators, and targets; and (iv) a final report 4 weeks after the 
final workshops and the receipt of comments on the draft final report from the government and 
ADB, satisfying all requirements of the TA.
